title: How can I be sure Riot won't retcon lore again?
body:
Honestly, that's one of the biggest problems with the lore fiasco for me. Riot's just retconning everything I liked, and it makes me worried for the future. What else will be retcon? Will they retcon their previous retcons because they don't like it? Will one of my favorite champs get a Trundle-esque relaunch?

I just don't feel like I can form any sort of attachment with a character or a part of the world without being able to know how long they're going to be here. Riot could just retcon them away and say something about how not enough people liked them or something. The new lore is always going to have the specter of 'this could change at any time!' hanging over it now.

replies.body: One of the many reasons retcons suck.

I'm fine with retcons as an emergency procedure to reset an oversaturated universe going nowhere fast. (Completely not the case with Old Runeterra)

What I'm not fine with is the way Riot handled it. Retconning should only be considered as a last resort, and discussed heavily with ALL parties involved before committing to it. Riot did neither, and came out with a seemingly brash decision to eradicate the world as we knew it.

Beyond that, they didn't seem have to enough content for the new world to back-up their plans of retconning the IoW, and now we're left with dozens of champions and other elements disconnected with this new vision of Runeterra. 

Retcons when done correctly should leave everyone elated (or relieved) after the process because the before product was such a bloated mess that seeing it reborn is actually a GREAT thing. Again, not so in Riot's case. Repeatedly we cried out "We love the JoJ style lore! Bring it back!" and Riot took that sentiment and pulled a 180, killing something that we thought was already dead. 

I'd be okay (well slightly less miffed) if Riot properly executed this retcon correctly, but the way they handled it all is what's most frustrating of all out of this whole process.

The retcon's I have seen and the others from the past have not been "character breaking." The worst is possibly Trundle.. A small, toxic swamp troll- turned into a large, powerful ice troll. But you still got yourself a club swinging troll- hell- even with an original skin. 

Retcon's to me that break a character is if .. Say they take Riven.. And make her an evil, male Demacian knight to rival Garen... That to me would be character breaking.

That being said, it is an investment to follow a character, but not all changes are terrible.

Trundle was an interesting change but also one in which they were trying to make him appeal to a wider audience, which is admirable. Being an ice troll is a bit better than being a troll covered in garbage. While I liked the original concept (and it was original), they kept as much of his theme and personality intact as possible while drastically changing his target audience.

In any case, Trundle is the only champion that has had his theme almost entirely modified, albeit mostly retaining his kit.

They did not keep as much of his character intact as possible. He never was power-hungry, he was cynical. He never was a brute (for a troll), he was a runt. They changed his character unnecessarily. I don't care about him being an ice troll, I care about him not being Trundle.

They could have made him an ice troll leading his tribe while still being old Trundle. They didn't , probably because the new one fit their story better. I have no faith that Riot will do everything it takes to keep old characters intact despite the retconning of the IoW.

Well he kept his kit, and he's still a club-wielding troll. So there's that.

His personality did have to change some to fit the new backstory, I'll give you that. But on the most basic level, Trundle is still the same **theme **as before. Key word here being theme because while remakes in general vary in severity, this is one of the most severe and they still managed to keep the same theme (maintaining most of his kit, physical attributes, playstyle, etc.).

In fact, his new backstory gave him a much more prominent role in Runeterra and we'll see more of him in the future. Under his old backstory, we weren't going to see any stories or tie-ins between him and other champions.

I'm not here for a theme, I'm here for a character. I'm not here for a troll, a time wizard and an evil little mage, I'm here for Trundle, Zilean and Veigar.

What do I care if this new character plays a more prominent role in Runeterra, it's not Trundle. I want to see stories about Trundle. All I'll be getting is his replacement. On top of that, they could have written *Trundle *leading the trolls in the Freljord instead of this brute. They chose not to or weren't good enough to make him Trundle.

I think for the most part (with very few exceptions) champions will maintain their themes and personalities, so feel free to enjoy the characters.

The backstories and in particular the details within those backstories may change. You should encourage the creativeness because what Riot is doing is not abandoning lore, but trying to look for ways to make it more interesting and opening doors to more interactions between the champions. You're likely to see more engaging cinematics and stories play out, and maybe even a movie one day. To do that, they needed to make a lot of changes.

In the process of the retcon they've opened the door of possibilities. They can do anything they want now with champion direction, map direction, etc.

So, while it might not have been necessary to retcon, I think it probably was the fastest way to rip off the bandaid (if you will) and now provides the opportunity to heal that wound with awesome content. I hope that they deliver.

Lacked depth? Could you explain this? And of course it restricted the possible lore, it also gave it direction and made the premise interesting. Now the premise is a generic mash-up fantasy world instead of a generic mash-up fantasy world with a UN.

They can do anything, they can bring in unicorns spreading peace and love and solving all wars. Having options doesn't mean we get good stories. Good writing means we get good stories. A good writer can just as well write good stories with a more restrictive premise, else he will write restrictions in the story himself so that there are obstacles to overcome and plot twists to happen.

I have no faith in the new lore after Trundle got replaced by a similar but definitely different character and the Freljord was all build-up, no climax. I don't expect Riot to deliver on the new lore and if they do, I won't be very excited, it could be retconned next year and all my investment would be gone *again*.

It lacked depth because only a limited kind of champion could be accepted by the Institute of War. They are also trying desperately now to separate what is happening in-game to what is happening outside the game, mostly so they are not restricted to the IP's media outside the game. Players have seen a little of this in their cinematics where abilities aren't EXACTLY as they are in the game, which is cool.

In any case, it's more a matter of freedom to outside of those restrictions than it is the inability to write within them. Sure you can continue to create the exact same champions and storylines within the rules they've set, but it turns out they'd rather not and to go outside of that realm of reality, they have to either break the rules, or rid themselves of the rules entirely.

I don't see why Runeterra can't have factions and rivalries etc. without the Institute of War. Don't get me wrong, I like the original concept, but as a writer I can definitely see why they're getting rid of it now and going on a different path.


Not 100% sure on what investment you lost from them changing the story, but it's cool that you're passionate about the game and the backstory. All of that original story is still there for you to enjoy... They're just changing the future of League of Legends. Consider it... An alternate universe.

A lot of people who frequent this board and who are against the retcon just wanted the old storyline to be progressed, that's why it totally sucked for us to have it cut off while a different one takes its place as canon. Meanwhile beloved characters change significantly too and that hurts those who liked them.

I invested in the old story, but that investment was betrayed when *Trundle was retconned out yet they told me it was still Trundle.* They said they wanted to keep characters intact, but they didn't keep Trundle intact. I can't be excited about mysteries if I don't know if the mystery is not going to be retconned out, unanswered or answered in a lame way. I can't be excited to read about my favorite champion if that champion is simply going to be retconned out. I can't invest in an ongoing story if I don't trust the writers to write a good story. I'm not one to read bad stories.

Why having the fantasy version of the UN, with all the ensuing political intrigues, would have meant a more shallow plot? If we look at the Kalamanda arc, we see a good story which makes use of this very "restriction" to deliver a rather intriguing plot arc in which we get the so craved character progression they aimed at being able to deliver with the retcon.
I'm not saying the retconned lore is not apt to deliver what they want, I mean that the old lore could do that too and (here is a personal taste) was more original.
The IoW and its members were not omnipotent and the JoJ has many instances of this: they didn't know Malzahar and Kassadin would clash and didn't stop them but the second time they battled and only because they were doing it near their facilities; Jarvan IV was the target of an assassination attempt schemed and executed by Swain within the very IoW and High Councilor Vessaria Kolminye arrived when a pretty violent fight had already taken place; the IoW's higher-up involved in the Kalamanda conspiracy got his plot revealed and was apprehended before he could seek asylum in Noxus.
This is just to argue the IoW was not only a restriction, but a possible plot device. For instance, if they started where they left, there was "outcry against the Institute of War in the streets of Demacia and Noxus" and all this could have led to the IoW facing a difficult political moment, with city states withdrawing part of their support. All this could have led to a weakening of the IoW's hold on some dangerous beings, like Brand and Nocturne & co.
I don't mean they should have gone with these stories, but it's a proof that plot could progress even with the IoW there. It was as much a restriction as the Ministry of Magic is a restriction for the Harry Potter saga.

Of course with the retcon of everything they opened up possibilities, because basically there is no lore right now for a major part of the world and its characters. Now comes the problem: they announced a retcon when they had no material to ship. It's been more than a month since then and we've got two stories for two champions out of the multitude of those for whom the IoW was a core part of their background (see Jax, Fiddlesticks etc). It was all extremely bad timed and that is the biggest remark that's been done.

The IoW may have been born because they wanted an easy way to get story into the game, but as they built upon it for two years it was no bandaid anymore, it was actually the very core and pillar of the LoL's experience. We are called summoners for a reason, the Influence Points are called that way for the same reason, the only true stories seeing characters' progression developed for the game were in the JoJ and in a setting with the IoW. As others pointed out, Noxus waging war against Ionia made logistically sense because at the boundary between Noxus and Demacia there was the IoW; without it Noxus sent its resources on a far away island opening itself to Demacia's possible aggressions. Since, if pieces of lore not involving the IoW stay canon as they said, there were precedents involving Jarvan IV, Swain, Garen and Urgot taking part in battles and their consequences (like J4's avoided execution and the subsequent death of Urgot), there's no real reason for Demacia not wiping them out while they were focused elsewhere.
Besides, without the IoW, how does Ionia come out of the Noxus occupation?
The point is: messing the timing on all this has made so that they opened a number of plot holes higher than the number of issues they wanted to fix.

This is what I meant by "it was sufficient, not necessary": they could have reached their goals with the old setting too, so it was not necessary to retcon, but surely retconning is a sufficient condition to achieve them because it gives you a blank state to work with. The cons being that, messing the timing, you have a game with no coherent and solid lore for a whole lot of time and if Riot's past lore deeds are to be kept in mind, then it could be *years* of such a state.
That's why a lot of people got pissed.
